timeline.author: losipiuk

timeline.bodyText:
Do we care about backward compatibility of the protocol?
With such implementation one will have to upgrade whole cluster at one go. Upgrading node-by node will not be possible.
Probably it is hard to workaround that now. But even if we make the backward incompatible change now, we can extend the protocol in such way, that if we want to add something here in the future, we can do that in a way which allows rolling upgrade. One option to achieve that would be to put an extensible structure (protobuf/json/thrift) in place of raw sequence of longs.
Not sure if that is worth of an effort though.
timeline.author: losipiuk

replies.bodyText:
Upgrading node-by node will not be possible.

it was never supported. E.g. currently, all nodes must declare same presto version or are not considered part of the cluster.
If we want to support rolling upgrade, we would need to do much more than just declare the intent.
Like certain provisions on the protocol level, but same for block serialization. Define version compatibility matrix/ranges.
And tests.
Since we're talking about this... I think this is dead end road in general. I am strongly convinced that rolling upgrade should be handled
on per-cluster rather than per-node basis. This delivers same behavior in most environments (except for fixed-size on-prem bare-metal
environments), with way lower complexity.
replies.author: findepi

replies.bodyText:
I am strongly convinced that rolling upgrade should be handled on per-cluster rather than per-node basis

I think I agree actually. The behaviour is not the same, but similar. The cost is a bit different - but should no matter in most of the cases. And the "bare-metal" situation is very problematic - not sure if we care though. And similarly to bare-metal situation, spinning up a HUGE replacement cluster may result in stockout in public cloud zone.
replies.author: losipiuk

timeline.bodyText:
Nit: Maybe extract method writeSerializedPagesHeader(int numPages) and put it in PagesSerdeUtil?
Or maybe MAGIC and pages count should be written by writeSerializedPages?
timeline.author: losipiuk

replies.bodyText:
Extracting write is nice, but it would call for extracting read as well. And this won't work, unless I introduce a new class for the header (count, magic).
It would be warranted if we wanted to pack more information here, or make the protocol extensible / future-proof, but since we don't have such plans, let me not do this now.
replies.author: findepi

timeline.bodyText: Oh - this one is nice. You can do it right if you try ;)

replies.bodyText: checksum verification & retry is reworked, please see new code
replies.author: findepi

timeline.author: losipiuk

timeline.bodyText: How does this surface to the user? It'd be ideal if it could be mapped to a proper error code.
timeline.author: martint

replies.bodyText: In practise, this is reachable only when checksum verification is OFF. This is then treated as if IO error occurred and retried.
replies.author: findepi

timeline.bodyText: How does this surface to the user? It'd be ideal if it could be mapped to a proper error code indicating there's a misconfiguration in the cluster (and skip the retry).
timeline.author: martint

replies.bodyText: The same way as a checksum verification failure, as in #3438 (comment)
replies.author: findepi

timeline.bodyText:
This is brittle. We need a better mechanism to indicate we want to retry than the type of exception. This logic to check for retry policy should really be in the code that performs the actual retries, otherwise there's a high chance it will get out of sync in the future.
We should throw a non-retryable exception in the case of configuration or a "checksum failed" exception otherwise. The code that does retries in HttpPageBufferClient should check the retry policy and act accordingly in case of "checksum failed".
timeline.author: martint

timeline.bodyText: nit: aren't we typically ordering methods that usage is first and declaration follows?
timeline.author: losipiuk

replies.bodyText:
updateChecksum is placed right under writeSerializedPage, because they need to stay in sync.
i added a code comment
replies.author: findepi

timeline.message:
Verify data integrity in exchanges

In our testing, a cloud's network proved to be not reliable. We observed
data corruption when transmitting data over TCP between Presto nodes
(internal communication unsecured, no compression).

Verify data integrity to prevent incorrect query results.

Optionally retry when data corruption is detected.
